Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Privacy-Preserving Distributed Storage and Computation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims at developing efficient methods for protecting the privacy of computations on outsourced data in distributed settings. The project addresses the design of an outsourced storage framework where the access pattern observed by the storage server gives no information about the actual data accessed by the client and cannot be correlated with external events. For example, the server cannot determine whether a certain item was previously accessed by the client or whether a certain algorithm is being executed. This property provides a high level of privacy protection that goes far beyond standard data encryption. The project also deals with advanced methods for verifying the correctness of outsourced computations, focusing on keyword searches and graph algorithms. The educational component of the project includes a curricular development effort for introductory computer security courses.

The project has applications to a broad range of web services widely used by business and consumers. Privacy-preserving access for outsourced data is relevant to web-based email and office applications. Also, it is especially important for the management of proprietary business data, medical data, and other sensitive personal data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has focused on computational issues related to privacy for large data, including cryptographic methods, data management schemes, and security protocols for data protection.  The project has applications to a broad range of web services widely used by business and consumers. Privacy-preserving access for outsourced data is relevant to web-based email and office applications. Also, it is important for the management of proprietary business data, medical data, and other sensitive personal data. The project is part of an NSF-funded collaborative effort by investigators at three institutions: Brown University, Harvard University, and University of California, Irvine. 

Joint work by the investigators has resulted in the development of efficient and secure methods for data storage and management that do not reveal the history of previous operations on such data. Hence, from the observation of the way the data is stored, one cannot infer the sequence in which the data items where inserted, or whether some data item was deleted.  These methods are based on new variations of classic data structures and on new techniques to manage the allocation of memory resources to a computer program. The motivation for this work includes electronic voting schemes, where knowing the order the votes cast may compromise the anonymity of the votes.

Additional results of the project include methods for enhancing integrity verification and privacy protection for data stored in the cloud. 

The project provided professional training opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students through research projects.
